description: From earlier bulldose (noun, literally “bull-dose, a dose fit for a bull”), equivalent to bull +‎ dose.

verbs.description: bulldoze (third-person singular simple present bulldozes, present participle bulldozing, simple past and past participle bulldozed)

examples: He's certainly very chirpy for a man whose house has just been bulldozed down.

entries.meaning: (UK) To push someone over by heading straight over them. Often used in conjunction with "over".
examples: He just ran across the field bulldozing everyone over.

entries.meaning: To push into a heap, as a bulldozer does.
examples: Again the animal had bulldozed all of its bedding into a heap at one end of its cage.

entries.meaning: (UK) To shoot down an idea immediately and forcefully.
examples: That was a good suggestion, but you just bulldozed it.

entries.meaning: (US, slang, dated) To intimidate; to restrain or coerce by intimidation or violence; used originally of the intimidation of black voters in Louisiana.
